item.title: Three Colored Columns
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row gap="10" equal_height="yes" content_placement="bottom"][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1478002731974{background-color: #f2c100 !important;}"][vc_custom_heading text="quantity" font_container="tag:h1|font_size:40|text_align:left|color:%23ffffff" use_theme_fonts="yes" css=".vc_custom_1478003055766{padding-top: 200px !important;padding-bottom: 15px !important;}"][vc_column_text]

These physical or physiological quantifications of color, however, do not fully explain the psychophysical perception of color appearance.

[/vc_column_text][vc_btn title="Learn More" style="outline" shape="square" color="white"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1478002750795{background-color: #007fe0 !important;}"][vc_custom_heading text="source" font_container="tag:h1|font_size:40|text_align:left|color:%23ffffff" use_theme_fonts="yes" css=".vc_custom_1478003067876{padding-top: 200px !important;padding-bottom: 15px !important;}"][vc_column_text]

Most light sources emit light at many different wavelengths; a source's spectrum is a distribution giving its intensity at each wavelength.

[/vc_column_text][vc_btn title="Learn More" style="outline" shape="square" color="white"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1478002768154{background-color: #ef004f !important;}"][vc_custom_heading text="brain" font_container="tag:h1|font_size:40|text_align:left|color:%23ffffff" use_theme_fonts="yes" css=".vc_custom_1478003073463{padding-top: 200px !important;padding-bottom: 15px !important;}"][vc_column_text]

The color of an object depends on both the physics of the object in its environment and the characteristics of the perceiving eye and brain.

[/vc_column_text][vc_btn title="Learn More" style="outline" shape="square" color="white"][/vc_column][/vc_row]
